column4: hey guys how can i make sure that i see ntfs volumes from programs...for instance when i use amarok i can't see my ntfs volumes where my music is stored...
i guess open office is fine amarok only looks at /
thats my problem possibly..give me a sec..
ubuntu mounts stuff in /media by default, but shows it in the 'Computer' location. However, some apps don't know about this so you have to point them directly to /media

next question...i have 3 160 gb drives...i just came from a windows world...so bare with me...i completely wiped out windows an am loving ubuntu by the way...i want to convert the other 2 drives that are ntfs...to linux....im used to just formating the whole things ntfs and make folders and saving data on those drives..do i just do the same thing with ubuntu and format them and create ext3..
yep, although Ubuntu can read ntfs too
so is there even a need to do that?  I guess what would be the benefit of me moving on that data around so i could get to ext3 on all my drives..
you only need to use a linux filesystem if you want to put linux on it
unless you want the benefits of ext3...
ok thats cool..i guess it would be go to leave the one drive ntfs as it is a portable drive that i often take to a friends house...he wouldn't be able to read it...
no need to defrag, journaling support (less likely to become corrupted), quieter
well that sounds like a lot better option to me then...is there anyway for a user to read ext3 in windows...maybe if i put an app on the portable drive that they have to install...
Ext2Fsd, but I think it must be installed rather than run from the disk. If you still need Windows to access it on a regular basis, you may as well stay with NTFS though.
its not a regular basis...maybe 2 times a year..i have taken it to a friends how to copy movies on to or whatever...
